    What do you need to learn React?

  • Basic familiarity with HTML/CSS/JS
  • Basic understanding of the DOM (Document Object Model)
  • Basic familiarity of Node.js and npm (Node package Manager)
  • A brain üß†

    • What is React?

    "React is a Javascript library for building user interfaces"

    What does a framework do?

    Let's try to create this effect

    HTML/JS/CSS

    <body>
  <div id="root"></div>
  <script>
    const div = document.createElement('div');
    div.textContent = Date.now().toLocaleString();
    div.className = 'container';
    document.getElementById('root').appendChild(div);
  </script>
</body>

    Frameworks are an abstraction to this capability

    Below is the React Implementation

    const dateComponent = () => (
  <div className="container">{Date.now().toLocaleString()}</div>
);

    Other Frameworks

    JSX Syntax (React Only)

    const element = <h1>Hello, world!</h1>;

    Counter Component

    0 

    import React, { useState } from 'react';
const Counter = () => {
  const [value, setValue] = useState(0);
  return (
    <div>
      <button onClick={() => setValue(value - 1)}> - </button>
      <h1> {value} </h1>
      <button onClick={() => setValue(value + 1)}> + </button>
    </div>
  );
};

    Counter Component (Vanilla)

    <div>
  <button class="decrease">-</button>
  <h1>{value}</h1>
  <button class="increase">+</button>
</div>

    const value = document.querySelector('h1');
const increaseButton = document.querySelector('#increase');
const decreaseButton = document.querySelector('#decrease');

upvoteButton.addEventListener('click', () => vote(value + 1));
downvoteButton.addEventListener('click', () => vote(value - 1));

    React Engine

    The Virtual DOM

    Instead of the traditional Document Object Model (DOM), which is a kind of tree-shaped data representation, React JS uses a newer concept - Virtual Dom

    Lifecycle Methods

    Why should we use React

  • Makes web applications Reactive
  • Has a vast javascript ecosystem with tons of packages
  • State/Prop data management
  • Helps organize websites into components

    • Why shouldn't we use React? üò¢üò¢

    • Large-Sized Library üçÜüò≤üò≤
    • Learning Curve
    • Usage of the virtual dom creates Overhead, which means the browser will load more files and code.
    • Coding in Vanilla or a Framework like svelte will often lead to faster builds and faster load times for browsers. This is only noticable on less powerful devices

    Sad

    What exactly is a component and what does it solve?

    • A Component is a building block of a react app
    • Components prevent you from creating a file that is 1000 lines long
    • Components help you reuse logic and keeps your code DRY (don't reuse your code)

    Props and State

    • Props or properties lets you are values you can pass into a component
    • State are variables that you can store in reactive data

    Functional Components

    Class Components

    Class Components

    class MyComponent extends Component {
  constructor(props) {
    super(props);
    this.state = {
      myState: 'New York'
    };
  }

  componentDidMount() {
    this.setState({ myState: 'California' });
  }

  render() {
    const { myState } = this.state;
    const { myCity } = this.props;
    const message = `The current state is ${myState}.`;
    return (
      <div>
        <p> The current city is {myCity} </p>
        <p> {message}
      </div>
    )
  }
}

    <MyComponent myCity="New York City" />

    Functional Components

    You would use a functional component over a class component if you simply do not need state.

    function Welcome(props) {
  return <h1>Hello, {props.name}</h1>;
}

    Functional components do not have state unless...

    Functional Components with Hooks üé£üé£üé£

    Hooks are a new addition in React 16.8. They let you use state and other React features without writing a class.

    import React, { useState } from 'react';

function Example() {
  // Declare a new state variable, which we'll call "count"
  const [count, setCount] = useState(0);

  return (
    <div>
      <p>You clicked {count} times</p>
      <button onClick={() => setCount(count + 1)}>Click me</button>
    </div>
  );
}

    Everything is a component

    React isn't just a framework, it's a way of thinking about a webpage
